race.name: Dusty Gravel Series - Andenne
race.tagline: Belgian Ardennes singletrack and Mosane valley terrain near Andenne.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Belgian Ardennes. Moderate elevation with scenic countryside.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Belgium event. Ardennes terrain with small-medium local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Dusty Gravel Series - Andenne is a regional event in Belgium—Ardennes terrain with moderate elevation. The Belgian countryside is scenic, but the small-medium local field, regional organization, and limited prestige keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Belgium gravel race. Worth it for Belgium/European riders. Not worth traveling internationally for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Belgium/Europe—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling internationally—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Belgium races: Flanders Legacy Gravel, Houffa Gravel.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Andenne has limited lodging. Consider nearby cities.

non_negotiables.why: Belgian weather is variable with rain possible.
Belgian Ardennes require sustained rolling effort.

logistics.explanation: Start was scheduled for 9:00 AM but delayed to 9:30 with no explanation, demonstrating what rider Alex calls "belgische Ruhe" (Belgian calmness). Race packets available one hour before start without the hectic nature of German amateur races, but the unexplained delay killed warm-up time and forced a cold start.

length.explanation: Two distance options available: 75km with 1000m elevation and 100km with 1400m elevation. The race starts with 1km through town then immediately hits an 8km climb that's very steep in the first 2km - what rider Alex describes as "mal so gar nicht meine Welt" (absolutely not my world). More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Surfaces that "teilweise nichts mehr mit einem Gravelparcours zu tun hatten" (partially had nothing to do with a gravel course anymore). Includes singletrack sections where riders risked falling 1 meter into ditches if they went off course. Belgian course design is "schmerzfreier" - more extreme than typical gravel. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The opening 8km climb hits you immediately after 1km through town, with very steep grades in the first 2km. The 75km route packs 1000m of elevation while the 100km option delivers 1400m through the rolling Condroz Namurois terrain - substantial climbing that separates riders early. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 56°F and lows of 40°F, with a 49% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 32 mph. The very rough course created mechanical carnage - "Das Rennen war von zahlreichen Defekten übersät" (the race was riddled with numerous mechanicals). Riders repeatedly struggled with tire punctures due to harsh surface conditions that punished equipment throughout the day. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Racing through the Mosane valley and Condroz Namurois keeps you at typical Belgian elevations - no altitude effects despite the substantial climbing through the wooded Ardennes terrain. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The route crosses Condroz Namurois and Mosane valley terrain that pushes beyond traditional gravel into MTB-like singletrack. Riders navigate wooded paths requiring technical handling skills to avoid going off course into meter-deep ditches - adventure through consequence.

prestige.explanation: 2025 race won by Lukas Malezsewski, followed by Adne Koster and Michiel van Vliet, but as a new series it lacks established reputation. Only 5 German riders among the 250 participants, suggesting limited international draw for this inaugural edition.

race_quality.explanation: The 30-minute start delay with no explanation undermined organization, though the Belgian calmness meant race packets were available an hour before start. Course challenges riders with varied surfaces from gravel to technical singletrack, but execution shows first-year growing pains.

experience.explanation: Part of Belgium Bike Festival described as "a 100% bike event for lovers of two wheels" with MTB, cyclo, gravel, demonstrations and exhibitions. The relaxed Belgian atmosphere contrasts sharply with German race hecticness, creating a distinctly laid-back cycling weekend vibe.

community.explanation: Belgian event culture with race packets available an hour before start and none of the hectic nature from German amateur races. Part of a 3-race Wallonia series with points rankings, drawing about 250 riders split between distance options for a solid regional field.

field_depth.explanation: 250 participants divided between two distance options, with only 5 German riders making the trip. Winners Lukas Malezsewski, Adne Koster, and Michiel van Vliet suggest regional competitive depth, but limited international participation for a first-year series event. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Part of Belgium Bike Festival weekend with exhibitions, demonstrations, and multiple cycling disciplines beyond just the gravel race. Series events typically run 120-159€ based on related Dusty Gravel pricing, delivering festival access plus challenging Condroz terrain for reasonable European standards.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs €60-80. Belgium festival weekend means premium accommodation costs, plus likely Brussels Airport transfer (~100km) for international travel. Series pricing typically 120-159€ for similar distances, with secure bike parking and finisher packages included - standard European gravel race expenses without budget-breaking elements. Higher total cost than Badlands.

citations.label: rsv-rheinadler.de: Dusty Gravel Series Belgien Rennbericht

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
